name: Boolean Pythagorean triples problem
summary: The boolean Pythagorean triples problem asks if the set of natural numbers can be colored with two colors (e.g., red and blue) such that no Pythagorean triple (\(a^{2}+b^{2}=c^{2}\)) has all three numbers the same color. The problem was solved in 2016, proving that it is impossible to color the integers this way, as a partitioning is impossible beyond a certain number. The solution involved a 200-terabyte proof generated by a hybrid SAT solver, which was then verified using specialized algorithms.
head: If the set of positive integers is colored with two colors
